abstract: On television and in the courtroom, the credit rating agency has waged war against a Justice Dept. lawsuit. But behind the scenes, it wants nothing more than to buy peace.
snippet: On television and in the courtroom, the credit rating agency has waged war against a Justice Dept. lawsuit. But behind the scenes, it wants nothing more than to buy peace.
lead_paragraph: On television and in the courtroom, Standard & Poor’s has waged war against a Justice Department lawsuit. But behind the scenes, the giant bond-rating agency wants nothing more than to buy peace.

headline.main: S.&P. Nears Settlement With Justice Dept. Over Inflated Ratings
headline.print_headline: S.&P. Nears Settlement With Justice Over Crisis

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies

abstract: S.&P. is nearing a settlement with the Justice Department over inflated ratings. | Antonio Weiss withdraws from consideration to be a Treasury under secretary. | Oil prices plunge. | Ethical questions of investing in pot.
snippet: S.&P. is nearing a settlement with the Justice Department over inflated ratings. | Antonio Weiss withdraws from consideration to be a Treasury under secretary. | Oil prices plunge. | Ethical questions of investing in pot.
lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s has publicly fought a Justice Department lawsuit, but behind the scenes, the bond-ratings agency now wants peace, Ben Protess reports in DealBook. “After S.&P. mounted a two-year campaign to defeat civil fraud charges ‒ portraying them as retaliation for cutting the credit rating of the United States ‒ the ratings agency is now negotiating with the Justice Department to settle the case, according to people briefed on the matter,” he writes.
